message: السلام عليم  ... شباب لو سمحتوا ... انا خلصت  HTML & CSS .... هو طبيعي ان الواحد يحس بلخبطة وهو بيطبق وخصوصا اني اتعلمت في حوالي 10 ايام ومش عارف هيا دي برده فتره طبيعية ولا ايه  ؟؟؟ يا ريت حد يفهمني الدنيا هتمشي ازاي ؟؟ وهو ينفع اتعلم جي كويري دلوقتي ؟؟ ولا لازم جافا سكربت الاول  ؟؟؟ يا ربت تساعدوني ...

data.message: سؤال :- إنت بتخطط تشتغل مهنة أيه ؟  UI Developer أو Front-End Developer ولا Web Developer عادى ولا لسة مش عارف ؟

Ahmed Moosa
انااا عاارف Web developer و عارف Web disigner 
اهااا معني ال 2 التخصصين التانيين اللي انت قولتهم ؟؟
yaret law te2der t3mele timeline asht8l 3leh  ??
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0zJiN4aHmXs الحلقة دي تحفة :D انا تقريبا بقيت انصح الناس منها عموما اسمعها جايز تفيدك بحاجة جديدة

UI Developer 
دا شخص بيقدر يقوم بتحويل الموقع كامل من صورة ثابتة مرسومة إلى HTML وطبعاً بيحتاج يظبط الـسلايدرز والحركة داخل الموقع بإستخدام JavaScript و JQuery وممكن مجموعة مكتبات تانية, من الإسم هو متخصص فى Developing UI .
تحديث :- بيتحاج طبعاً يعرف CSS كويس , علشان يظبط التصميم .
Front-end Developer 
ممكن تقول دا , JavaScript Developer , لإن كل تركيزه عليها, لكن بيختلف إنه بيتعامل مع الـ Server  فى شوية مهام
يعنى  بيتكلم مع الـ Back-End من خلال Javascript .

Mohammad Tayseer 
ياريت لو نظرة شاملة سريعة على 
 Front-End Development 
؟

To answer your question, yes it's normal to feel like this and no don't learn jQuery yet. Learn Javascript first, Javascript is not jQuery and you won't get far with jQuery without strong knowledge of Javascript. 

- UI Developer/Front end Developer are the same thing

- PSD to HTML workflow is dead.

- Existing web practices frown upon the use of pictures that induce effects easily replicable in pure css.

- Dead because browsers are capable of supporting cutting edge CSS3. Dead because your goal is to have a web page that looks great and loads fast, images don't align well with this agenda. 

-Dead because even the browsers that would require such a drastic fallback are going out of service.

- However, the workflow exists and is still used. So a person that can turn a PSD into HTML/css, can also do your entire front end and  also develop in Javascript . If she can't then shame on her, but that's not the norm
------
Ibrahim Elkhatib There are usually three roles in any modern web project:
1) Backend developer
2) Frontend developer
3) Web designer

A backend developer is largely responsible for programming the "web application". Web applications are in a nutshell, applications with a web interface. So this means, they are comfortable working with a full-featured programming language (anywhere from C to Ruby and anything in between)

We also tend to call them "Web developers". Why? Because a professional Web developer is capable of working both roles, a Backend and Frontend. As a web developer, you need to be comfortable working in css, html, javascript and any backend technology you choose

A frontend developer is largely responsible for anything that lives on the client side of the spectrum. They're attentive to details, usually have a sense of design and are capable of producing some breathtaking interactive user interfaces

Web designers in a large sense, are the people that imagines how a website would look like, a modern web designer should she be forced to produce a PSD, must be able to turn this PSD into HTML and CSS.

Good web designers are also usually comfortable with only html and css but no javascript, so hiring someone? don't expect much from them beyond that.

There is also a role that's getting more and more blurred, called the User Experience designer/Usability Engineer (UX designer)
These people are largely responsible for designing the user experience of your user interface, in terms of what works better for a use-case, user scenarios, user personas, colours, colour theories and their effect on a user, interface interactivity and page/task flow

They tend to produce items like Wireframes, low and high fidelity ones. UI Mockups and anything else relevant

The role is being blurred because it's a distributed responsibility (amongst web designers, frontend and backend engineers)

Best of luck.

Hady Ahmed
